instruction: How did the researchers validate the performance of the mobile hyperspectral imaging system in recognizing different surface objects, including crack detection?
Output: The researchers validated the performance of the mobile hyperspectral imaging system in recognizing different surface objects, including crack detection, through experimental validation. They developed a machine learning methodology with classification models that involved four different feature extraction processes. By using hyperspectral pixels in conjunction with dimensionality reduction, they were able to achieve outstanding potential in recognizing eight different surface objects, including crack detection, with an F1 score of 0.962. The performance of the hyperspectral imaging system was compared to gray-valued images with a higher spatial resolution, and it was found that the hyperspectral imaging system outperformed the gray-valued images. This experimental validation demonstrated the potential of computational hyperspectral imaging for automating damage inspection in structural materials, particularly in complex scenes found in built objects in service.

instruction: Can the mobile hyperspectral imaging system and machine learning methodology developed in this work be used to automate damage inspection for structural materials in complex scenes found in built objects in service?
